awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Energy Efficient Thermal Design of Heterogeneous System with Active Cooling
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to make major advances in the energy-efficient thermal design of heterogeneous systems by enabling thermo-electric-based active cooling for efficient control of on-chip thermal field to manage and eliminate hotspots and minimize spatiotemporal thermal gradients. The approach is centered on a holistic modeling and 3D simulation framework that strongly couples the sensor design, dynamic control principles, thermo-fluidics model, and device optimization model. 

Intellectual Merit: The research integrates techniques from electronic devices, thermal physics, and solid state cooling for the development of a physics-based integrated 3D framework.  This integrated framework will develop distributed sensor-driven, real-time feedback methods to activate on demand active cooling on chip and establish guiding principles for eliminating the bottlenecks of active cooling in 3D heterogeneous system. The research will lead to optimized thermoelectric device properties and develop system-level sensing and control principles for enabling efficient active cooling in a heterogeneous system.

Broader Impacts: The sensing and control methods for active cooling on chip and assisted device optimization methods are expected to have a transformative impact on the development of energy-efficient electronic systems and software tool chains. The research will integrate education through graduate course development and preparation of a model tutorial on 'Hot spot management,' which will be posted on nanoHUB.org.  Undergraduate students will be advised through the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship program and the Discovery Park Undergraduate Research Internship program. Participation in Facilitating Academic Careers in Engineering and Science for African-American students and Summer Undergraduate Research Experience for minorities will facilitate involvement of underrepresented minorities in the research program.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The time varying power density of different components on an electronic package results in spatiotemporally varying thermal field and thermal hotspots. Efficient removal of localized heat and mitigation of thermal gradients on chip can boost the performance of the semiconductor devices, increase the energy efficiency of the system, enhance the system reliability, and extend the system lifetime. This program has developed (i) a holistic modeling and 3D simulation environment to enable the energy efficient design and thermal management of electronic systems using thermo-electric based active cooling, (ii) control circuits and systems for on-chip control of thermoelectric devices for on-demand cooling, and (iii) experimentally demonstrated the control circuits and techniques using test-boards and CMOS test-chips. This program has coupled the thermal model, dynamic control principles, and device optimization model for efficient control of on-chip thermal field in order to manage/eliminate hotspots and minimize spatiotemporal thermal gradients.

Outcomes (Intellectual Merit): This project has implemented an energy efficient system that uses the same thermoelectric module for cooling a chip as well as harvesting energy during nominal power modes. For the first time, a fully integrated on-chip system has been presented for energy-efficient on-demand active cooling using dynamic mode switching of thermo-electric module. The project has first developed a detail thermal simulation environment of thermoelectric (TE) devices embedded within the package of an integrated circuit (IC), which has been used to analyze the potential of an array of thermoelectric coolers (TECs) in cooling hot spots in 3D packages, or energy harvesting from the waste heat of chip. An integrated compact thermal model of IC packages with embedded TE devices is developed to perform electro-thermal analysis of on-demand cooling using TE devices. The integrated model includes detail distributed RC based thermal models as well as transistor level model of control circuits and principles. The developed numerical as well as compact models demonstrate the effectiveness of transient cooling using TECs over prior approaches of TEC based DC cooling. The analysis further shows that optimal design of the cooling current pulses improves effectiveness. Moreover, placing the TE devices closer to the silicon die, instead of the heat spreader, can provide more effective cooling. A set of control principles has been developed to exploit TE devices for on-demand active cooling.

The control principles aim to regulate chip temperature below a target threshold under varying power dissipation of the chip while minimizing the energy overhead associated with the cooling has been developed. The CMOS circuits are designed to realize the control principles for on-demand TE control. The circuits are designed for on-chip integration using low-voltage devices, to reduce energy dissipation of the controller, and to enable fast operation of the controller. The control policies are developed to exploit the energy harvesting capabilities of TE devices to time-multiplex the same TE device as harvester and cooler to significantly reduce the energy overhead of TE based cooling.

The on-chip cooling using TEC including potential of autonomous TEC-TEG mode switching has been experimentally demonstrated. First, a test-board has been designed using the discrete devices and commercial TEC. The measurements are performed to demonstrate the on-demand cooling using TEC where cooling current is passed when temperature is above a threshold. The proposed controller also uses the same TEC to harvest energy when temperature is below a threshold.
